column1: Which component of the axon may contain Nissl's granulations?
column8: Nissl bodies (RER + ribosomes) are present in the soma and dendrites only. They are absent from the entire axon, including hillock, initial segment, and terminals.

column1: According to the shape of the secretory portion of the exocrine glands, they are classified as:
column8: Classification by shape refers to tubular, acinar (alveolar), or tubuloacinar glands. Other options describe location, secretion type, or secretion mechanism.

column1: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the adipose tissue?
column2: It is important for the immunological defense of the organism
column3: It has an important endocrine function
column4: It contains unilocular or multilocular adipocytes
column5: It has an important metabolic function
column6: It can be located in the subcutis or around the internal organs
column8: Adipose tissue has metabolic and endocrine roles but is not a primary immunological defense tissue.

column1: What is the normal percentage of the monocytes out of the circulating leukocytes in healthy adults?
column8: Normal leukocyte differential: neutrophils 60–70 %, lymphocytes 20–40 %, monocytes 5–8 %, eosinophils 1–4 %, basophils <1 %.

column1: Macrophages in the tissues are derived from which of the following blood cells?
column8: Monocytes leave the bloodstream and differentiate into tissue macrophages as part of the mononuclear phagocyte system.

column1: The mesenchyme is an embryonic:
column8: Mesenchyme is embryonic connective tissue derived mainly from mesoderm and gives rise to connective tissues, bone, cartilage, and muscle.

column1: Which of the following glial cells participate in the movement of cerebrospinal fluid?
column8: Ependymal cells line the ventricles and possess motile cilia that circulate cerebrospinal fluid.

column1: All of the following answers are true EXCEPT: The glycocalyx is composed of:
column8: The glycocalyx is a carbohydrate-rich cell coat made of glycoproteins, glycolipids, and proteoglycans. Lipoproteins are plasma transport particles, not structural membrane components.

column1: The diameter of actin filaments is approximately:
column8: Actin filaments (microfilaments) are the thinnest cytoskeletal elements, measuring about 6–8 nm in diameter.

column1: Identify the depicted organelle:
column8: Mitochondria are identified by a double membrane and internal cristae seen on electron microscopy.

column1: A genetic defect in the motor protein dynein is linked to which disorder?
column6: None of the answers is correct
column8: Dynein defects impair ciliary motility, causing primary ciliary dyskinesia, classically Kartagener syndrome.

column1: Ribosomes attach to which organelle:
column8: Ribosomes bind to the cytosolic surface of rough ER during synthesis of secretory, membrane, and lysosomal proteins.

column1: What type of cell junction is the desmosome:
column8: Desmosomes (macula adherens) are strong cell–cell anchoring junctions connected to intermediate filaments.

column1: Which of the following statement IS TRUE? Chorionic villi form the fetal part of the placenta.
column2: Chorionic villi form the fetal part of the placenta
column3: Chorionic villi do not form the fetal part
column4: Chorionic villi form the maternal part of the placenta
column5: Chorionic villi form the entire placenta
column8: The placenta consists of a fetal part (chorion frondosum with villi) and a maternal part (decidua basalis).

column1: From which component of the blastocyst can be isolated stem cells capable of organ regeneration in humans?
column8: Pluripotent embryonic stem cells are derived from the inner cell mass (embryoblast).

column1: In the beginning of the 3rd week the paraxial mesoderm differentiates into segments known as:
column8: Paraxial mesoderm segments into somites, which later form sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.

column1: The number of oogonia at birth is approximately:
column8: At birth, ovaries contain about 1 million primary oocytes arrested in prophase I.

column1: The second meiotic division of the female gametes is complete at:
column6: None of the answers is true
column8: Meiosis II is completed only upon fertilization; otherwise the secondary oocyte degenerates.

column1: At the eighth day of development the hypoblast consists of:
column8: In the bilaminar disc, the hypoblast is composed of small cuboidal cells, while the epiblast is columnar.

column1: Trophoblastic overgrowth with lack of embryoblast development may lead to:
column6: None of the answers is true
column8: Excess trophoblast proliferation with absent embryo is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole.

column1: High number of nuclei →
column8: Osteoclasts are large multinucleated cells responsible for bone resorption.

column1: Prominent RER →
column8: Plasma cells synthesize immunoglobulins and therefore contain abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum.

column1: Simple squamous →
column8: Endothelial cells line blood vessels and are simple squamous epithelial cells.

column1: Derive from monocytes →
column8: Macrophages differentiate from circulating monocytes.

column1: Contain myofilaments →
column8: Myofilaments (actin and myosin) are defining components of muscle cells.
